comments.commentBody: And I thought it was boring in Fairfield, WA...

I spent over one year in Greenland and Newfoundland. From Narsarsuak, Sondrestrom to Thule I marveled at the glory of this land.
Certainly with some social help the native s could be helped because it can be a wonderful life.
I am very surprised no one has mentioned Terroni.  Multiple locations, always packed... maybe it is because it is so good that everyone wants it to be a secret.

I agree with LInda @1, this puzzle did take longer than usual for a Tuesday. It wasn't that hard, but for some reason it just took longer. Of course I'm up a little later than I like to be during the week, and my brain may have stopped functioning.

I also like the scissor kick for swimming. It's a nice leisurely stroke that you can keep up for a long time whereas the crawl wears me out quickly. The breast stroke is also relaxing and kind of meditative.
Im not so sure Torre is healthy enough for another go around as manager... his color looked terrible at the Steinbrenner worship memorial-- all jaundiced.
As is everything else at the new Yankees Mallpark, it's oversized and tasteless.  It's an embarrassment.  Steinbrenner deserves respect, but this is really a bit much.

Yeah...thanks to George and the inane money he poured out, it is now impossible for a kid to attend a baseball game, and get a decent seat, for less than a C note. When I was a kid, I could go to a Met or Yankee game, pay $1.50 for a seat high up but right behind home plate and on many Sundays, could see 2 games for the price of 1.

Try that today. Using the sale of my parent's house, bought in 1961 and recently sold as well as the subway fare as examples, that $1.50 general admission ticket should be $22.50 (subway fare went from 15¢ to $2.25; parent's house went from $20,000 to $300,000 (add a zero and add half which is 1500%...the $3.50 box seat should be $52.50 which should be the highest price one has to pay for a regular season baseball game. The fact the Yankees charge as much as $2,500 for a seat to a game, all bnecause of the asinine salaries Steinbrenner (as well as others but he was by far the worst) threw at the players is why kids of today can't enjoy a day at the ballpark like we all did when I was a kid.

For this, one can understand why Bud Selig thinks he should be in the HOF. But for the average fan, think of this the next time you want to go to a baseball game (and yes, other teams do the same things but nowhere near to the same extent).
This is disappointing. I think Klinsmann would have been a HUGE boon for the USMNT.

Wow.  Now-- Gulati's fate is intertwined with Bradley's... a poor result in 2014 (if Bradley makes it that far) should also doom the man at the top.  It looks and sounds like Klinsmann really wanted the job.
I do not discount Bradley, but I speculate as to what the team might have been and what it would have achieved, had Klinsmann been hired in 2006.
wonder why the chinese, second seeded in the women's olympiad starting tomorrow, did not participate.

Q4. Here is an algorithm in pseudo code.

Label the balls 1, 2,..., 6.

1 vs 2
If 1=2
    1 vs 3
    if 1=3
        1 vs 4
    else
        4 vs 5
    end
else
    3 vs 4
    if 3=4
        3 vs 5
    else
        5 vs 6
    end
end

I loved today's puzzle mainly because I am a swimmer. and I am hitting my 100 miles for the year this week, and I like the back stroke. I did a lot of it today watchng the kid divers at our faciltiy.

I liked the great misdirect on the clue for BACKISSUES. I also like the misdirect for ISUZU. Don't think I've seen BMOCS, ANIMA, and DECAYING in puzzles lately.

Amusing that I could get both LITTLE EVA and EMIL Jannings without thinking almost, but took me a long time to come up with MALTA.

I think my head just exploded. Mistreating women and lying is honoring their culture? Yes, dressing girls as boys is a practical way to avoid problems, but a more practical approach would be to change the rules that cause the problems in the first place.

The solution may be found in a quote from the article: "In a brief period of marital trouble, he once attempted to beat her, but after she hit him back, it never happened again." Dress all girls as boys and send them to martial arts classes.

Oh, and somebody break the news that a baby's gender depends on the father. A guy over there could change wives his whole life and still produce only girls and never figure out that he was to "blame".

When all women's face are covered and no one knows what a woman looks like; women can pass as men. Maybe Afghanistan will turn into the first unisex country where all people are men. No "women" will be force to walk behind men or be accompanied by men when outside.

All intereting things aside, that is one screwed up country.

This is one of the most interesting articles I have read in a really long time.  Please keep studying this phenomenon and contribute more!  The topic is so fascinating to those of us who have seen women's rights grow over the years in the US, and it also can make us turn an eye inward to ourselves on some topics.  We see this phenomenon here too (for different reasons, obviously), and let's not pretend we're so far enlightened to all accept it.

So why are we still in Afghanistan? Obviously the cultural differences are so great we can't begin to influence them, nor should we try. This is reason #251 to withdraw our troops immediately. Nothing good can come from remaining one day longer.

Interesting that none of the fathers who desperately want sons to help with work, as companions, to inherit property do nothing to change the laws or their own attitudes towards valuing girls and the women they become.  They find a way around the rules instead of changing them.

This is strange and sad. What a great pity that girls are so little valued in that culture (and many others). I have to wonder what the effect of this has on gay children too (who of course have no status at all).

This story is very depressing. Pressure from society and family towards having boys is not confined to Afghanistan only but it is there all over Asia. In India and China, some families go to illegal ultrasound clinics to get rid of female fetuses. This is leading to unbalanced sex ratios.

Thing is, if Afghanistan really followed Islam--none of this would happen.  The Qur'an states that all children should inherit a portion of their parents estate. (Son inherits twice that of a sister--as it is assumed that he would take care of his sister, and then she would also benefit from her husband's support.)  Both men and women are to seek education.  Girls are supposed to have a say in marriage.  Etc.  And also..one is not supposed to dress like the other sex.  Yet for all of that, part of me is happy for these girls who find a way to escape the confines of their culture and live a bit freer--if not forever.  It's strange...Afghanistan seems to really like transgendered people... more than any other culture/place I know.  Not only are there these "bacha posh"... but there are also the young boys who dress as girls "bacha bazi". (See the Frontline special). For those that recommend "Osama", just be forewarned, the ending is very disturbing.

“In a land where sons are more highly valued, since in the tribal culture usually only they can inherit the father’s wealth and pass down a name, families without boys are the objects of pity and contempt. Even a made-up son increases the family’s standing, at least for a few years.”

If a girl would have dressed like a boy. It must be tough for the girl and encounter some difficulties. Such as: how she solves her bathroom problem? If she has been treated like a boy, then, how would or will she adjust her life physically and psychologically when she grows up.

Fantastic. Instead of greater equality between men and women, and between girls and boys, we instead have girls "becoming" boys, which ultimately doesn't challenge gender discrimination in Afghanistan AT ALL. I really can't see how we, in the U.S., expect Afghanistan to become a self-supporting democracy when Afghanis, by and large, won't even recognize that a person with a penis and a person without a penis are equal.

You can't change people who don't want to change. Add the extreme geography, widespread illiteracy, continued presence of the Taliban and various other terrorist groups, etc. etc. and you have a recipe for one thing and one thing only: a country of absolutely nothing at all.

Women are half the world's population yet they are a cultural underclass. We are certainly smart enough and strong enough to do so many things and yet we remain deprived of equal rights and often subject to harsh rules that leave us physically and financially dependant on males that think only to their own power and control and use us as sex objects and breeders.

Males determine the sex of a child and punish women for bearing girls. A woman's sexual life is subject to a male interpretation. An object of desire, she will be punished for his difficulties. Women are sold in marriage as objects. We live in the 21st century and the outrage for such behavior remains mild at best.
Afghanistan also sells it' poor children into sexual slavery. The war in Afghanistan has nothing to do with its people and all about world politics.

What will it take to convince the Afghani's that their culture--where people riot over the idea of burning Quran, but bombed and destroyed the priceless bamiyan buddas, where a free election is all but impossible, where people are still stoned for adultery, where women have been suicidal since the Taliban returned to power and ordered them back to the stone age, where young girls have acid thrown in their faces for going to school, that they are never going to be productive members of the world community without relinquishing their misogyny?  This is not culture, this is psychopathology.
